There are waiters to order lunch and always cool water on hand to drink (no charge). When it was time to check out you could do it by phone or over the television system. I had a staff member print my boarding passes for me and I knew that I was going to miss this place. The only way to make it better is to take it out of Phoenix and move it to Sedona.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Old Lady needs some TLC”
Reviews.Author: alaskabobAnchorage
Reviews.Content: We arrived from Anchorage Alaska in 113 degree heat. Our room was not ready untill one hour after check in time. The grounds are beautiful but directions to our room were vauge and we wandered around untill we found it. The shower door was broken and nobody ever did come to repair it. Resort fee? What did I get for this, ice water at the pool. Nine pools? As far as I could tell only 2 were usable by anyone. TV was pathetic 27". Even Best Western has flat panels. Hotel and grounds were top notch. By the end of our stay I really fell in love with the place, but am glad I only paid off season prices. It was a great experience to stay in a clasic resort, but I will not be returning. The room was nothing as pictured and we had the best available other than a cottage. Staff was great. Its sad that this place may fold if not updated and competitivly priced.

Reviews.Title: “The Arizona "Hidden Fees" Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: SLeal75
Reviews.Content: $25 Disclosed Resort Fee + $3 Housekeeping Grautuities/night automatically added, not disclosed + $10 Self-park/night automatically added, not disclosed + $15.50 Banquets/Conference Group, automatically added, not disclosed + $12 Bellman/night, automatically added, not disclosed, didn't even use!!! and never offered. Total undisclosed fees: $3X2, $10X2, $15.50, and $12 X 2: Total EXTRA for a 2 night stay: $65.50 plus $50 for the resort fee.... Anger---Priceless.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Grounds but Pathetic Service Standards”
Reviews.Author: Flyintl
Reviews.Content: Perspective from a very frequent business traveler who is also a member of the highest tier in this hotel chain's frequent stay program. GOOD: The grounds are nicely manicured and the original Frank Lloyd Wright buildings are iconic. Service at The Biltmore Grill is good. Upgraded king room is spacious. BAD: The pathetic service starts upon arrival. The Valet/Bell Desk will not offer to help with your luggage. The Front Desk will give you keys that don't work, causing you to return to get keys that do. It'll be a 5 minute walk to your room in the summer 100+ degree temperatures. The clock radio will be broken. The coffee maker you request (there are none in the room) will be delivered with a used filter and coffee grounds in it. Housekeeping will wake you by banging on your door at 7:00 am and will call twice when you don't answer. The fitness center will start turning off the lights and the TVs 30 minutes before closing (8:30) even though you're working out. You'll be told there are no umbrellas to borrow when the lightning storm comes. Upgraded king room bathroom is shabby and the shower very small. Food at The Biltmore Grill is over priced for the small portions. In room safe is not large enough for a small laptop. RECOMMENDATION: If you want to experience the Arizona Biltmore, just visit for a meal or a drink, but stay at any of the following: Royal Palms, The Phoenician, Fairmont Scottsdale Princess, Sanctuary on Camelback, The Boulders, Westin Kierland, Ritz-Carlton or Four Seasons Scottsdale.

Reviews.Title: “A great setting, great architecture, failing on some details”
Reviews.Author: VonKrieger
Reviews.Content: The hotel's claim to fame is its’ architecture, being done in the prairie style of Frank Lloyd Wright, and the hotel remains true to that vision. If you like Wright's work (and I do) there is plenty of eye candy for you to look at Check in: Easy, went well, no issue Parking: We used the valet...tho they did charge $25/day for parking which I thought was rough. Food Bar: I did not eat at the hotel. The bar was good, staff friendly and of course, the drinks were overpriced. Room: Neat, well kept, clean, and remained true to the theme of the the hotel. I also liked the showers. Now for the complaint; the resort has several pools...the main pool was, in a word, filthy. The water was so cloudy that one could not see the bottom of the pool. There were several contributing factors to this. First, it had rained, and I was told by the hotel staff, rain water tends to overwhelm the pool's sanitation system. Secondly, there is a swim up bar which serves food, not a great idea if you want to keep your pool clean, and finally, the pool was really crowded. Aside from the cloudy water, I noted some refuse in the pool as well. Aside from the pool problem (which I am sure could be fixed with a little attention) the place is great. Good setting, nice staff, etc. Oh! One more thing, the concierge service was fantastic; helpful, nice people who really seemed to care.

Reviews.Title: “Unique”
Reviews.Author: jcolesw2
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for one night at the end of a ten day road tip through Arizona, Utah and Nevada and it made for a perfect ending to a great holiday. The design and architecture of the building is beautiful and made the Biltmore, in my experience, something very unique and very special. The grounds too are beautifully laid out the pool is incredible. I loved the style, furniture and character of the room. This was large with a decent sized balcony, two very large and comfortable beds and a very large bathroom. We ate in the hotel and both the service and the food were good. I found this reasonably good value. We had breakfast from the coffee shop and again this was fine. The outside bar area is a lovely atmospheric spot to relax at any time of the day, but especially the evening when fires will lit which helped create some atmosphere. Hotel staff were not outstanding but were efficient and courteous. The Biltmore is a very special place being truly redolent of a by-gone age and has managed to its credit, to maintain its unique and special atmosphere. It’s not cheap but I thought it worth every cent and would return to Phoenix solely to stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Blah and more Blah”
Reviews.Author: venice4504
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for a conference. Horrible wait staff at meals. Food is overly expensive and not very good. Pool is drab and the rooms are downright boring. You'd think for the price that you pay to stay there that the rooms would at least have nice beds and duvets...but oh no...they don't. I'd never go back.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Hotel if your boss pays for the stay!”
Reviews.Author: g1wzwnd
Reviews.Content: I spent four days at this hotel due to a business trip so I heard many comments from all my colleagues. I personaly had a room with balcony, kitchen, two floors and two queen size beds. The room was big, plasma TV, nice pillows and towels and a comfortable bed. The shower had no pressure and one morning I noticed water falling hard from the ceiling from the room above. it did get fixed however other colleagues mentioned AC and shower problems. One smart colleague asked to see rooms in each wing until she found one she liked so if you have time, do just that or try to stay away from the old wings of this hotel. The bar is nice and the drinks are great but (yes another but) service is lousy because they only have two servers around the bar and drinks are expensive ($16). The grounds are beautiful, the pools are very nice and friendly to the kids and the golf course is just ok. All in all a great stay but if I had to pay for it I would choose another destination.

Reviews.Title: “Watch for the hidden fees”
Reviews.Author: zeeno7
Reviews.Content: At the time of booking, I was told that there would be a $25 per day resort charge added to the room fee. However, I was not told about numerous other automatic fees that would be added to my bill including: a $12 per day bellman gratuity (even though I didn't use the bell services); a $10 per day parking charge (even though there is a large, open parking lot where you park yourself); and a $3 per day housekeeping charge. I was very disappointed that a hotel in this price range would nickel and dime their guests with additional, undisclosed fees. Hotel accomodations and grounds were nicely appointed and well kept. However, the rooms were merely average compared to other properties at this price level. In addition, this property is very spread out, so be prepared to do a lot of walking between your room and the facilities. Similarly, the hotel is quite isolated, requiring a car to visit any attractions, restaurants, etc.

Reviews.Title: “Eh.”
Reviews.Author: lashy52
Reviews.Content: I honestly just don't understand all the fuss about this hotel. We booked a room with a king bed but they still had to scrounge for one when we arrived. The grounds are nice I suppose, but everything is quite pricey and it's much more sensible to leave the property. But, Phoenix is a city that really requires a car in order to get around, yet parking at the hotel is hard to come by. Many of the conveniences of upscale hotels are lacking, such as coffee in the room (you have to either go find some on your own or order it from room service). The room itself was fine but I could have gotten a similar one at any mainstream chain hotel. I admittedly did not take advantage of the spa facilities, but as for the hotel itself, I don't see what makes it so great. It's an average hotel for an exorbitant price.

Reviews.Title: “A++ Staff, A++ Pools, D- Room Service!”
Reviews.Author: summ3r
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Biltmore for four days during a corporate event. Rooms: They had initially put us in a room in the "Village" area. The room, decorated with mission style furniture, overlooked a garden and was spacious and clean, with a dresser, desk, two comfy chairs, side table, king bed, and flat screen tv. Our friends had rooms with a balcony and I love sitting outside reading so I requested a change to a room with a balcony. The staff were extremely accommodating about making the change. We packed our bags and they moved them for us. When we came back in the afternoon we had been given a room with a balcony, again overlooking the garden, in the "Paradise" section. Again the room was clean and had a flat screen tv and king bed. It had the balcony I had asked for but it was MUCH smaller! It didn't have room for the dresser and while it was a reasonable size, it felt cramped compared to the other room. To tell the truth, I wish I'd kept the larger room! So take your pick: smaller room + balcony, larger room + no balcony. Staff: Professional, helpful, polite, accommodating. Everyone we came in contact with, from Reception to the Pool staff, was top notch. The Grounds: You will walk. A lot. This isn't necessarily a bad thing but if you are mobility restricted it can be an issue. The Resort is large and sprawling so be warned, if you are in a room in one of the farther buildings and you are attending an event in the McArthur Ballroom, it's right on the other side of the property and is a bit of a hike. Lots of fountains, gardens, swimming pools, and everything is meticulously tended. btw: If anyone from the Resort reads this I'd have a small suggestion, on the way from the lobby to the Paradise building there is a concrete "Japanese Temple" on a rock. It doesn't look right just plopped there like an afterthought. It's an anomaly in a place as carefully planned as the Biltmore. The Buildings: The Resort itself is beautiful and it was a pleasure to stay in a place that had been designed with such style. We noticed that as sometimes happens in Wright's work, style occasionally triumphs over function, but it is lovely nonetheless. And ignore the picky people who complain about the carpets, plastic toilets in the rooms or whatever. Some people can never be satisfied. It's a beautiful and extremely well maintained Resort, and it's a pleasure to visit. And finally, I must mention the room service. If you have any choice, don't. We had to order in one evening because my husband was feeling ill. I love french onion soup and was eager to have some because I was sure that in a place as prestigious as the Biltmore, it would be real french onion soup. Can I tell you how disappointed I was to taste the same nasty oversalted "beef" soup base I can get in any restaurant? I sent the first bowl back because it was so salty it was inedible. The second bowl seemed almost as bad as the first but I was starving by the time it came and ate it anyway. The gruyère cheese on top was correct and lovely, but the overall it was very disappointing. One bowl french onion, one bowl chicken noodle, one grilled cheese, one small milk, one crème brûlée = $50. Expensive and disappointing. Overall the Biltmore was a treat.

Reviews.Title: “The Jewel of the Desert still shines!”
Reviews.Author: Cuse1
Reviews.Content: The Arizona Biltmore is 5 star all the way! I just returned from a conference held at the Biltmore and frankly cannot do justice to this hotel in words (but I'll try!). I have been fortunate to travel extensively in North America and have stayed at many fine hotels but the Biltmore beats them all. The main building is architecturally stunning and the landscaped grounds are off the charts beautiful. In addition the staff are very well trained, extremely polite and respectul, and actually seem to really enjoy their jobs which is reflected in their attitudes. My wife and two children came with me to the conference and they had a great time. The Biltmore has several pools including one with a large water slide. The pools by the way are open 24 hours a day. There is also an 18 hole putting course on the grounds that we made use of. The rooms have been redone recently. Our room featured a 42" high definition tv's, a very large bathroom with two double sinks, seperate glass shower, and sunken tub, and a huge closet. The concierge service was incredibly helpful to me as well, booking an excursion for my family to Sedona, getting baseball tickets to the Diamondbacks game, providing directions to the hiking trails, and printing out our boarding passes. My only complaints, which are minor, are that the food and drinks in my opinion are overpriced, even for a high end resort. A bottle of corona for example was $7.50. A hamburger was $15.50. Also the resort has only two real restaurants on property which with over 700 rooms get very busy. To be fair, there is a small cafe with a take out menu as well as a limited menu available at the main pool bar. Of course there is always room service. In spite of these small complaints, I highly recommend this hotel and hope to stay there again soon!

Reviews.Title: “Nice But They Nickel & Dime You”
Reviews.Author: CharlotteHokie
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Arizona Biltmore for 4 nights in mid-April. The resort grounds are beautiful, but be warned that you’ll likely do a lot of walking as it covers a lot of area. Overall it was a very nice place, but we probably won’t stay there again. It’s a little more costly than what we usually like to spend but we were treating ourselves. In addition to the daily room cost, they charge you a $25 daily resort fee and $10/day for self-parking ($24 for valet) and while we knew all this upfront, I believe hotels should include the resort fee in their prices instead of tacking them on after the fact. We had a great time at the main pool (Paradise Pool) and rented a cabana one of the days. We chose a “Classic” cabana which includes its own bathroom with shower, fridge, TV, table and chairs, ceiling fan and lounge chairs. It cost $150 for the day, which was lower than what I had been quoted, a nice treat. There is also a “Premier” cabana option which is $100 more- these are supposed to be on the sunny side of the pool while the Classic is in the shade. What we found was that ours was actually in the sun for a good part of the day so I was happy I didn’t pay extra for the sun option. A few things we enjoyed: the grounds are beautiful and there are some fun lawn games offered for everyone including chess, checkers (the giant pieces- very fun), and croquet. There are several pools on the site and while we only used the Paradise Pool (the only one with a bar and café), the others also looked nice. Our room was very large with a large bathroom and a large flat screen TV (most channels were in HD). A few things we didn’t enjoy: the last day we were there (Friday) they didn’t clean our room until around 4pm. The other days they cleaned much earlier so I’m not sure if it was b/c it was a weekend day and they were more fully booked. While the bathroom was large, there was no door on the toilet room so it was open to the rest of the bathroom and closet area. The TV did not face the bed. When we arrived, our ice bucket was filled with water. The last night, my husband’s pillow reeked of sour milk as if it hadn’t been cleaned. We self-parked our car and under the guidance from the front desk, we used the parking garage to keep our car out of the sun all day. The last morning, they had blocked off all entrances/exits to the garage with barricades so we had to move one of them out of the way in order to leave for the airport.

Reviews.Title: “Scratching by on its reputation from decades past”
Reviews.Author: Colin_from_NY
Reviews.Content: If you generally stay at places like the Four Seasons, the Arizona Biltmore will prove very disappointing. My family continues to grow, so I was seeking a two bedroom suite. On the face of it, the Biltmore provided a much more attractive proposition that the Four Seasons. Our suite cost $1000 per night approx (Feb. 2008 rates), vs almost double that for the Four Seasons. It was on the qualitative front that this hotel fell short. The lobby is shabby, the reception desk people unengaging. The room was tired and worn. Old, dirty looking carpets and furniture throughout. The TVs (three) were CRTs as opposed to the advertised flat screens. The cappuccino machine used by room service was on the fritz for three days! Three days to get a cappuccino maker serviced! Pools were dirty. The list is endless. We finally checked out and I wrote a letter of complaint to the client service manager and never even received a reply. That sums up the approach to client service in a nutshell. To sum up. Fine if you are looking for a bargain five star hotel but do not expect a five star experience. This is a property in absolute and relative decline.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: MeijiBlack
Reviews.Content: We decided to splurge and stay at the Biltmore for a long weekend (Easter weekend). The hotel grounds are beautiful as are the building exteriors. We stayed in the Valley Wing on the ground level facing the pool. Our room was nice and we enjoyed sitting on the patio at the end of each day. Two things: (1) the noise of running water from the room next door. Someone decided to take a shower early one morning (3:00 a.m.) and the sound of the running water woke up my husband; (2) maybe because it was Easter weekend but there were a lot of families staying there. My husband and I are in our 40s without any children so we prefer to stay in places that do not cater to families with young children. We chose the Biltmore because of its history; I think if we found ourselves in Phoenix again we might choose to stay elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing and gracious”
Reviews.Author: PRVeteran
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Biltmore for four days. The grounds are spectacular, as is the architecture. We loved walking the grounds and lounging in the Adirondack chairs by the fire pit. The lobby is beautiful and there is so much history with this hotel. Our room (Valley room 3324) was very spacious and clean. The bed was comfortable and the bathroom was a good size. I was surprised at the lack of a coffee pot. I was also disappointed that the robes were so rough on my skin-they need to use fabric softener on them! We rented a car. Parking was adequate, but very far from our room. We self parked ($10 a day) as opposed to valet parking (I think it’s $28 a day with in/out privileges). The hotel is only a short 15 minute drive from the airport. We ate off property most of the time, with recommendations from the very friendly concierge staff. Our favorite meal was at Element. We ate outside under a heater and thoroughly enjoyed our evening. It’s about a fifteen minute drive from the Biltmore. We ate breakfast at the grill on property- it was very good and fairly priced. One evening when we ate there again for a late night bite, I had the tortilla soup and my husband had the steak quesadillas. Our meal was good and Scott, our waiter, was very nice. He brought me extra tea bags, as I wasn’t feeling well. Watch out for the walk up café- $9.75 for two Cokes!! Yikes! We would definitely come back to the Biltmore. It was a relaxing stay at a beautiful, historic hotel. PS Go see the views from the Wrigley mansion-just a short walk from the Biltmore. Take the tour, if you have time. The Sunday brunch looked out of this world, but at $43 a person, it ought to be!

Reviews.Title: “Look out for hiden costs”
Reviews.Author: bhaimsohn
Reviews.Content: The property of this hotel is beautiful and is worth the staying here. The issue I have with my last stay is the following: "When I checked out I noticed that the hotel had charged a resort fee of $20, maid fee per day and bellman fee." They need to have this on their web site when you are booking a room so you know exactly how much you cost is going to be and should be explained to you in detail when you check-in. Ideally they would hand you a piece of paper explaining exactly what these fees are for, so you could review them in your room. I ended up tipping people during my stay not knowing that in general this was being charged on a daily basis during my stay.

Reviews.Title: “a wonderful stay”
Reviews.Author: JLSToronto_Ontario
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a 3 day, 3 night stay at the Biltmore (Wed - Sat) and I think there were tears in my eyes when I pulled away last evening! It was truly a pleasure from the moment I checked in until I left. I paid in advance for a deluxe resort room in the Valley wing which was large with a lovely balcony overlooking Camel Mountain to the left and the large lawn and a glimpse of the Paradise Pool to the right. I was travelling alone (woman, mid 30s) and the staff made extra sure I was comfortable regardless of what I was doing. They remembered me from the front desk, to the restaurant, to the pool. Normally when I travel, I use the hotel for sleeping only, this was not the case for this vacation. The only time I left the resort was when I went shopping on Friday at the Biltmore Fashion Park (free shuttle service) and the Fashion Square (5 miles down on Camelback Rd). Two of the evenings I ate on the outdoor patio of Wright's Bar and was able to order food from the Grille. I also spent 2 full days in a cabana by the pool where the staff were attentive and lovely and I also had a terrific, relaxing massage at the spa one of the early evenings. Because I was there mid-week through the weekend, I noticed a huge difference in clientele. Mostly business men and women Wed-Fri and then families on the weekend. The pool was much livelier on Saturday and I recommend splurging for the cabana to escape from the noise and sun if necessary. I loved my stay here and would recommend it to single travellers or families. I hope to return for many more vacations.

Reviews.Title: “This Grande Dame is holding up beautifully!”
Reviews.Author: OCTravelAgent
Reviews.Content: I had to spend a couple of nights here for meetings, making this the 4th time I've stayed at this resort. I've always been struck by the contrast of the stark Frank Lloyd Wright architecture against the sumptuous landscaping of its grounds. I had a resort deluxe room in the Paradise wing overlooking one of the many pools. The room was impeccibly maintained, with workdesk (free wired internet), 2 sitting chairs and dresser-mounted high-definition LCD television. I found the bed to be very comfortable. Closet space was large, but dresser space was somewhat limited. The marble bathroom included 2 sinks and a combo tub shower with curtain. Service at the hotel was always friendly and prompt, and I was always greeted with a smile and a 'hello'. Given the nature of my stay, I wasn't able to sample either the spa or the golf, nor was I able to try any of the restaurants other than the casual Biltmore Grill, which was an excellent choice for lunch, both in terms of menu and service. A word about the parking: this resort was not designed with cars in mind, so self-parking is located on the perimeter and can be quite a ways from the guestroom. Valet parking is available, but can be pricey. That being said, I would still recommend this hotel as one that compete with any of the large deluxe resorts in Scottsdale - yet it is more convenient to downtown Phoenix and the airport.

Reviews.Title: “Huge Disapointment! Not a luxury hotel.”
Reviews.Author: sunlovingPortland_OR
Reviews.Content: This was the biggest hotel disapointment that I have ever had! My wife and I scheduled a long weekend in Phoenix and wanted to try the Biltmore for something different than our usual stays at the Phoenecian or Royal Palms. There is no comparison....the Biltmore is very dated, has horrible service in the restaurants, and is somewhat depressing inside. Even in a suite, you almost feel as though you are in a dungeon. We joked that it was somewhat similar to the "tower of terror" ride at Disneyland. The worst part about it is that we were woken up early 2 out of the 3 mornings by the groundscrew and their leaf blowers outside of our room. We ended up checking out early and spending out last night at the Royal Palms...and were happy we did!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful escape from the snow, however....”
Reviews.Author: Ozblossom
Reviews.Content: Positives: the property is beautiful - lawns well manicured, beautiful scenery, quiet and relaxing (amazing when you take into account the number of pools on the property - all beautiful and well designed). Beds were very comfortable with housekeeping just adequate. The outdoor fire pit seating arrangements at the bar are heavenly! There is also a paved & gravel walk/bike trail that extends for miles both east and west of the property - well travelled and a nice change from the indoor gym. Hourly transfer to nearby mall - very nice shops. Negatives: added charges - surprising in light of the already high daily rate, restaurants on property are fair - also with very high prices. Housekeeping service very late in the day. The outdoor grille area is very nice, but cold on a Feb evening with limited heaters available. Kudos to: Scott the Assistant Front Desk Manager who went out of his way to address any needs and make our stay as enjoyable as possible; Frank the bellman who was on top of everything! Recommendations: Enjoy the lovely outdoor seating before going off property to dine. Walk/bike on the trails. Get acquainted with Scott and Frank - they'll remember your name and make you feel like an honored guest - just what you expect for a property of this rating.

Reviews.Title: “Alright, but not spectacular.”
Reviews.Author: Pramstroker
Reviews.Content: Having stayed - in the last year - at the Sanctuary and the Montage, I expected the Biltmore to be of the same caliber, given that it was in the same price range. Don't get me wrong - it was good, but not that good. Sure, the unique architecture of the "old building," both inside and out, is remarkable. The service is impeccable. However, the inside of the "new" buildings was not up to my expectations. I stayed in the Arizona building, built long after the original building, but a long time ago. The hallways reminded me of a run-of-the-mill Marriott. The "half-moon" lights down the hallway doubled as dead bug receptacles. The room was spacious and the furniture and appointments okay, but not plush. It really reminded me of an apartment I lived in 20 years ago: hard plastic sink and bathtub, '80's style light switches, and double-mirrored closet doors that won't stay on their tracks. The carpet had stains as did some of the chairs. And the sliding glass door to the outside (no balcony, just iron bars), had a shabby "afterthought" night lock that looked like "Uncle Bob" slapped up. In this era of "Spa Resorts," it seems like the emphasis is more on the spas and not so much on the facilities. (I had a similar impression of the Phoenician also.) Next time I go to Phoenix, I'll try the Ritz or Four Seasons (if they have locations in Phoenix).

Reviews.Title: “Best Customer Service”
Reviews.Author: GlendaleCA
Reviews.Content: Have stayed here many times, and the customer service maintains its super high level. This is true across all types of employees from bellman to front desk to housekeepers. Food at the Biltmore is also quite good for a hotel... The grounds are kept up very well. Now they just need to freshen up the rooms a bit to match the grounds. Plastic sinks and shower inserts is kind of a surprise at such a high level resort. The prices for such a high level resort are surprisingly low as well.

Reviews.Title: “If you love history and architecure, this is a must-stay resort”
Reviews.Author: illflyaway
Reviews.Content: I have read many of the reviews of the Arizona Biltmore and have been so surprised at some of the negative ones. If you are a lover of history and a lover of architecture, you MUST stay at this hotel. It is a true gem, a return to the 1930s. It was designed in 1929 by a student of Frank Lloyd Wright, and Wright served as the consulting architect. As you enter the main pool area (there are actually eight pools on the grounds) and view the Art Deco water slide and the shaded cabanas, you will feel like Clark Gable may walk out at any minute. It is a beautiful hotel, with lovely manicured grounds filled with palm, orange and kumquat trees. We stayed in a room in the main hotel (the original building) and the rooms were appointed with mission-style furniture and extremely comfortable beds. The service was excellent. We had an incredible view overlooking the mountain and the courtyard. In the interest of complete disclosure, I did have two complaints: the noisy groups who gathered around the fire pits late at night., which were on the main level right outside of our second story room. Had it not been for the earplugs I always carry, I would have found sleeping a problem. Also, the prices for amenities - drinks, dinner, spa, etc., were quite expensive. If you love history ,take the historical tour of the hotel offered from the concierge desk several times a week - it's fascinating. I highly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Beauty in the Desert”
Reviews.Author: devotedtoarizona
Reviews.Content: We live just outside of Phoenix and finally stayed at the Biltmore. It is a beauty. The history behind it is reason enough to stay. The rooms were nice, the property is just wonderful to explore. The front desk service was great. There is a trendy bar with inside/outside seating and 2 huge firepits to cozy up by. We ate at Wright's which is very pricey but it is worth it. We really enjoyed our stay. It takes you back to the times when romance was alive. A must see is the hall of history. Has pictures of prior celebrity/presidental guests - also the many pools are wonderful. This hotel was on the travel channel and prompted us to finally go.. We are so glad we did.. You can also tour the Wrigley Mansion that is just above the hotel (that we weren't as impressed with)...

Reviews.Title: “Spectacularly at Peace at Arizona Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: Quizzler
Reviews.Content: Attended a 4-day conference here at the end of November. Gorgeous grounds, wonderful conference halls, very good conference food catered by the Biltmore, and a spectacular room! Have seen comments here that the rooms seem quite outdated so perhaps I was lucky, but my room was very up-to-date, very large (with a very nice, and very large, bathroom--separate tub and shower), and had a full balcony (third floor) with a beautiful view of the Biltmore grounds (and absolutely lovely view of the fall Arizona sunsets). None of my conference companions had any complaints about their rooms either (although none of them had as big of a room with a full balcony). Huge LCD TV with a large number of channels, including 2 HD channels (HBO and Showtime if I remember correctly), very comfortable bed. My only complaint about the resort is the exorbitant cost of eating there---even breakfast is outlandishly priced---and the main dining room, ridiculous. And the Resort is not really near any other places to eat (although, during the day, there is a free shuttle to a shopping mall with several semi-decent, not fancy places to eat---think the shuttle goes until 6 p.m.). But really, had one of the most relaxing times in a very long time and at one of the most beautiful venues I've ever stayed at. And the staff was very good and very competent----based on other reviews, that is apparently not always the case.

Reviews.Title: “Wish we could have stayed longer”
Reviews.Author: GranolaGal
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for two nights. This is very much a conference hotel, but we found it was fine for tourists as well. The Frank Lloyd Wright inspired cast block lobby and buildings are very formal and monolithic compared to some places we've stayed, and the interior spaces are a little darker than some hotels. But it's comfortable and relaxing. We found the staff here to be friendly. The gardens, fountains, pools and landscaping are georgous. The hotel terrace in the late afternoon has a fabulous view of the mountains and is a marvelous place to sink into the comfy rattan chairs and have a drink - they light the fire pits when it gets cool out. The prices are a bit on the high side but the ambience is worth it. We ate breakfast and dinner at the Grill. The food was delicious, atmosphere pleasant, and there wasn't a wait to sit down. The wait staff was great - well trained, knowledgeable, polite, friendly, attentive but not intrusive. This was our first stay and they upgraded us to a room with a private balcony and a mountain view - nice! It had rained a few days prior and the balcony was filled with water. We considered asking for another room, but we liked the room so we decided to call the front desk to ask if someone could just squeegee the water. We went to get our luggage and by the time we returned, the water was gone. Someone came by a little later to give it a second sweep to make sure it was done to our satisfaction. We were very impressed with the speed with which this request was handled. The rooms are large, the furniture is big and heavy (craftsman style oak). The plant in the room was a nice touch. The bathroom was huge w/great shower and toiletries, plenty of towels, two sinks, separate area for the commode, make-up counter with a chair, and closet with full height mirror. The only complaint about the room is that the closet for the room is inside the bathroom. There are plenty of outlets in the room to charge your electronics (phone, camera, etc.) We liked that they not only have glasses in the bathroom but wine glasses and tall glasses. We liked this hotel so much that we considered canceling our next hotel so we could stay here an extra day or two.

Reviews.Title: “Historic and Pleasant”
Reviews.Author: Dan_S_NYC
Reviews.Content: The weather was perfect and the resort was a nice place to spend a couple of days. The is a very obvious Frank Lloyd Wright influence to the architecture. Had a serious mosquito problem in the room which put a damper on things bout otherwise I would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “A resort, get your wallet”
Reviews.Author: roadwarrior30
Reviews.Content: RECOMMENDED. An expensive resort, so fundamentally it was nice. I was there for a conf with 600 people with all food being provided. Service was nice throughout. Banquet food was a bit iffy, not bad, just not outstanding. Some food selections were just downright bad, which isn't acceptable, remove them from the menu if you can't do them well. Free internet access throughout was a bonus but it was slow slow slow. Purchasing food/spirits was very expensive. Rooms were well maintained and a service request was promptly handled. Bathroom well illuminated but small (I was in main building). While close to shopping, it's not walking distance, though a shuttle runs regularly. Like most resorts, you're landlocked. For a conference there were multiple buildings and it was a bit confusing. Overall, nothing bad, just there may be better choices for your own convention in the Phoenix area.

Reviews.Title: “Charming”
Reviews.Author: zanderc
Reviews.Content: This is a charming historic property with all the modern amenities. The rooms are quite spacious. The dining selections are wonderful with excellent service. Charming gardens surround the buildings and include a croquet lawn and large lawn-chess set. The hotel has an interesting history, of which they are very proud. The setting has a resort feel but is only minutes from many fine dining and shopping options.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel with average rooms”
Reviews.Author: traavel74
Reviews.Content: The hotel grounds are excellent but I was disappointed by the quality of the rooms. Although the room was large, it had little or no ambience and was in a wing of a hotel that seemed to be built as a significant afterthought in an effort to create more space to generate more rooms for conferences held nearby. Generally not impressed for a hotel of this calibre/price range.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible place”
Reviews.Author: mmvvl
Reviews.Content: This hotel is overprice!!! To be honest is not worth spending the money. the food and all the is overprice and is not good. There is no coffee pot, the water cost 5 dollars for a little bottle. A glass of milk is 4 dollars. the staff is very rude and they don't know anything. the rooms are very small with no views. the pools are always closed when you want to go, or there is no towels. The only people who are helpful are the hispanics that work there.

Reviews.Title: “Okay for a very SHORT stay only”
Reviews.Author: Flippitti
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for one night August 18, 2007. Overall, we had no significant problems during the 24 hours of our stay. August is low season here but we didn't see a change in the level or quality of service we've come to expect from a Waldorf=Astoria hotel. It was 112 degrees when we arrived so we opted for valet parking ($24/day) rather than self-park ($8/day). The self-parking lots (one is covered, one is not) can be quite a walk depending on the location of your room. Check-in was quick and easy. Front desk staff were polite and formal but very helpful. The Biltmore consists of a series of separate buildings, villas and cottages accessible by meandering walkways. Some are covered, most are not. Finding our room in the Valley Wing meant wandering around and taking wrong turns in the heat because the map we were given at check-in was not helpful. Don't rely on the map, look for the small signs posted around the grounds directing you to different buildings. During low season, room rates are about 50% of high season rates. Our resort room wasn't worth more than low season rates, all very average - king bed, a couple of chairs and ottoman, desk, large closet, 42" flat screen tv, a large patio with seating. Not much of a view. Furniture is Crafstman style and looked dated and carpet was worn. There are small signs of neglect - for example, one of our lampshades had a big rip in the fabric that was pretty obvious and we had a burned out lighbulb on the desk lamp. Bathroom had double sinks, an oversized tub and shower combo, lots of plush towels but very few hooks to hang anything on. Our room also had two very large bath robes to use. We had a good night's sleep on the comfy king bed. The A/C was quiet and kept the room cool. Walls are thin - we heard voices from a couple rooms down, a TV show, toilets flushing and showers running. We even heard someone's alarm clock go off early the next morning! No coffee maker or microwave. There's a small fridge with minibar items - $3.75 for Coke or bottled water, $3.25 for a Butterfinger candy bar. In other words, the usual high prices. About 30 minutes after arriving in our room, the kitchen delivered a small plate of 4 dessert samplers and two bottles of water compliments of the Biltmore for being Hhonors members. It was a nice little amenity. One of the pools was open pretty much all night. There are lounge chairs, tables and limited bar service. The Biltmore also has 24 hour kitchen staff in case you get the munchies at 2AM. We sat by the pool around 10PM when the temperature had dropped down to 100 degrees. No mosquitoes. We had a light breeze, friendly waitstaff. A few smokers were around but they were downwind of us. While the room we stayed in was quite average, the grounds are quite immaculate and beautiful with lots of grass, fountains, a giant chess set on the grass, the Biltmore "sprites" statuary and all that Frank Lloyd Wright inspired architecture. Inside in the public areas, it's almost like being in a museum. Take time to browse the hallway between the Bistro Grill and Wright's where you can see photos of the Biltmore in the early years and of the celebrities who stayed there. There are several small shops near the Cafe that we browsed through featuring high-end resort clothing, shoes, jewelry, and Biltmore souveniers. We didn't use any of the spa services. As beautiful as the grounds are, we wouldn't stay here again. Rooms are really just average and restaurant prices are quite high. The resort charges for every little thing. There are quite a number of much nicer resort hotels in the Phoenix/Scottsdale area to stay in.

Reviews.Title: “over priced and disappointing stayed 5th-10th july 07”
Reviews.Author: pleen66
Reviews.Content: the hotel looked nice overall with the grounds and swimming pools were great with the 24 hrs swimming, but it was so over priced, it was criminal!! the food was boring and over priced, the staff on check in were very unhelpful, but problems were solved by manager who was very helpful! rooms were average and disappointing, expected a lot better, seeing as they charge the earth for it! the one major problems were being eaten alive by mosquitoes!! so be aware to have some repellent handy! Overall, i was very disappointed with the Biltmore, i wouldn't stay there again, make sure you have planty of spare cash as you're gonna need it!

Reviews.Title: “A desert classic!”
Reviews.Author: ASU_Sundevils
Reviews.Content: We (me, wife, 6-year old daughter) stayed at the Biltmore the nights of July 6-7. I grew up in Phoenix and have always known the Biltmore by reputation; however, my only experience with the facility had been several nice meals at the restaurant at the Biltmore's golf courses. I booked the room through Hilton's web site and got a $116 per night rate (plus resort fee and tax). We got to Phoenix quite early and called ahead to get an early check-in (11:30 when check-in time isn't until 4:00). The front desk emplooyee who answered the phone was extremely courteous and accomodating. When we got to the hotel the valet staff was courteous and helpful (although we self-parked). At the front desk I was told that I had requested a king bed (this is in my HiltonHHonors profile). When I pointed out that I was traveling with my daughter the front desk person immediately looked for a different room. She quickly found one for me. I further pointed out that I planned to self-park, then she said the room she had was far from self-parking so she would try again. She then said, I have a very nice room for you but it only has one king bed. She made it very clear that it was an exceptional room and that I would like it. I took her advice. I stayed in the Saguaro Villas - what an nice room. This is a full-blown suite: 20-foot ceiling, enormous patio, floor to ceiling windows looking north to the mountains, fireplace in the living room, full kitchen, large bedroom, walk-in closet, etc. The VIllas are owned by other people and Hilton manages them when they are in the rental pool. The Saguaro villas have a small, but beautiful, pool if you don't want to be in the large pool area. My only complaint with the room (and this is minor) is that it is dated and needs to be refurbished. The maid service was very efficient. Spending time at a Phoenix-area resort in the summer is quite popular with the locals and the Biltmore is no exception. By 9:00 a.m. all of the shady spots (with umbrellas) had already been claimed at the big pool. Of course, there were no people at these spots - just their stuff. During the day the large pool was a giant party. A wide variety of people having their own fun - singles, couples, families, young and old. The swim-up bar is nice and the prices are in-line with what you should expect at a resort (and actually cheaper than what you'll pay at many of them). The resort fee entitles you to use the spa, which is a nice use of the $25. At most resorts the fee lets you use the gym but the spa is an extra charge (or completely off-limits unless you purchase a treatment). I worked out both mornings and it was nice to finish the session in the spa lounge with some fresh fruit and fresh-squeezed orange juice. My gripes with the Biltmore are minor. First, I think the hotel needs to do a better job of embracing the desert. There is way too much grass on the property - this is irresponsible from a water usage perspective and in the summer the brown areas look horrible. Second, the decorative brick with the distinctive art-deco design is in need of repair. Throughout the exterior of the hotel the brick is cracking or has fallen off the wall and been poorly replaced. We had breakfast the first morning in the restaurant and found it to be incredibly mediocre. The pancakes were as dry as the desert. Will I be going back? Probably not. Why not? Because the Phoenix area has so many wonderful places to stay and I want to try them all! But I highly recommend the Biltmore!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: KJR0711
Reviews.Content: Terrific property with first class service and rooms. The pools are great, restaurants delicious, and employees among the happiest and most helpful I have dealt with.

Reviews.Title: “Scorpion in room, rude staff”
Reviews.Author: sjf621
Reviews.Content: Overall our stay was great until the last night when we found a scorpion in our room. Hotel sent an exterminator who harassed us about making such a big deal out of the scorpion. Next morning at the checkout desk I overheard the maintenance man, manager and 2 other employees making fun of the incident and our reaction. Not the type of service you would expect from a resort hotel such as this.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel, Perfect for a corporate retreat”
Reviews.Author: loveislands
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Biltmore in December for a business conference. I think most of these trip advisor reviews are very accurate... it is a beautiful hotel with fabulous grounds and architecture, but the rooms need a renovation. My room was a very nice size (overlooking the pool) but the furnishings/decorations were generic and a little outdated. The hotel restaurant was excellent, and I enjoyed sitting around the pool area. For a spa destination like Phoenix/Scottsdale, the fitness center and spa amenities were not impressive. There are many business travelers who stay at this hotel, and it is the perfect place for a conference; however, I wouldn't want to use my own money to vacation here unless I found a great rate or if they renovate the rooms.

Reviews.Title: “A great getaway in Phoenix!”
Reviews.Author: Artistgirl27
Reviews.Content: I was planning a big 30th birthday party and wanted to go to a spa resort in Phoenix. My mom wanted to go to the Arizona Biltmore, as she had been there a few times before and loved it. I booked the hotel and got a pretty good rate with my AAA membership. I was apprehensive about going to the hotel after reading the bad reviews here, but my friends, family and I had a great time! First of all, I don't know why people are saying the rooms where bad. We stayed in a resort King, and it was really nice. Nice bed, big bathroom and everything was clean and comfortable. It didn't seem outdated to me at all. My family's rooms where even better than mine! The hotel is divided into cottages and different room buildings, and our building had its own little pool which was quiet and nice. The hotel was pretty crazy, as we went Memorial Day Weekend and there were two or more weddings taking place, but I thought it was really fun. The large pool is a mob scene and people come and stake out pool chairs at around 7 am! If you come after 8 am, forget about finding pool chairs. It's a fun pool with a swim up bar and a water slide. My friends and family and I decided to hang out at another pool- the Arizona pool- on our first day. It was smaller and more mellow, but it had a bar next to it and was quite nice. They even had a barbeque going and we all had great burgers, chicken & fish. When my husband picked up the tab, we were amazed at how cheap it was! The total bill for our lunch for eight was under $80. The hotel also has a lot of fun activities for kids, and great extras that make it fun for all ages. On Friday night we went and had s'mores by the fire pit. They had an amazing setup of s'more stuff, lemonade, cider, and popcorn, and even had a "cowboy" come and sing some songs for the kids. This was a totally free event, and really fun. There is also a movie night by the pool, which we missed, and croquet, a putting green, and a large checkers/chess board by the pool. All eight of us also went to the spa for massages and hot stone pedicures and one facial. We all tried different types of massage, and everyone had a good experience. It's not the fanciest spa and in a town of great spas I'm sure it's not the best one, but it was clean, there were great drinks and snacks, and all of us enjoyed our experience there. The other issue that someone mentioned is parking. There are two self parking lots when you pull up to the hotel. One is to the right, and closer to the lobby, and the other is a parking garage that is a bit farther to the left. We found parking in the close lot a few times, despite it being a busy weekend, and the other times we parked in the garage. Yes, it was a little farther away, but certainly not a mile, and not a big deal. I think my only complaint would be about the "resort charges" which are $20-$25 per day, but other than that I had a great time at this hotel, and I would certainly go there again!

Reviews.Title: “Hated the place”
Reviews.Author: california_oregon
Reviews.Content: The Arizona Biltmore was extremely disappointing. The rooms were old, probably last upgraded in the 1980s. The furniture was broken, and didn't look very different from a low-end motel. Second gripe was on the billing -- they charged me for valet parking ($24 per day) when I self parked ($8) with a mile long walk, charged me for minibar expenses which I never used, charged me fictitious expenses at the gift shop. After I called and got the charges revoked, they charged me $10 for delivering the revised bill. Go figure !!!! The hotel conceirge packed us off to a restaurant which was closed, so we had to return to the hotel for food. The menu listed the pasta as angel hair with fresh roma tomatoes, parsley, olive oil and garlic. It was the worst thing on earth -- boiled pasta with some sun dried tomatoes thrown in. The burger we ordered came without fries & without ketchup. Absolute yuk for $60. Never understood the exorbitant fees they tagged on for everything. All in all, the romantic weekend with 2 breakfasts & 1 lunch cost $1000. I would say it was worth a third of that. Yeah, the hotel grounds are pretty, but just about everything else sucked. Honestly, if I could give this place 0 stars I would.

Reviews.Title: “Service Is Lacking”
Reviews.Author: BFree90
Reviews.Content: I was disappointed with the service at this hotel that holds itself out as the favorite of celebrities and US Presidents. I got to the hotel at 3:00 pm and it took 45 minutes for my room to be prepared by housekeeping. The only offer the front desk staff made to get me into a room immediately was a room of lower value, but not to one of upgraded status. When I did get to my room, I placed an order with room service at 3:55 pm. I was told that my order could not be placed until 4 pm since I was ordering items off the "dinner" portion of the room service menu. I told the guy that 4 pm was 5 minutes away, and he told me there was nothing he could do. For a hotel holding itself out as an elite destination, they did not provide an elite level of service. One additional caveat, the rooms are small (I was in a deluxe king room in the main building), and at night I could clearly hear conversations in the next room as well as outside on the patio two stories below. I have stayed at the Royal Palms and the Phoenician, I would recommend them over this location.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful architecture & setting, So-so rooms, Pretentious service and policies”
Reviews.Author: TANSTAAFL1
Reviews.Content: Like many landmarks, the Biltmore is an experience you should enjoy once, then decide whether it merits a return stay. The main buildings are “Frank Lloyd Wright influenced” designs (built in the late 20's, but Wright is not the architect of record - although he was associated with the project), the grounds are stunning and maintained meticulously, and the surrounding views are spectacular. I found desk, concierge, restaurant and poolside service alternately harried and aloof. My sense was that line staff were too few and lacked proper training, while managers were generally indifferent to routine operations and most interested in cashing in on added-charge, personalized service opportunities. Event and guest self-parking (traveler beware - this is an extra charge NOT noted when reservations are made!) is atrocious - long distances to lobby, meeting and lodging areas. The shuttle is too infrequent for the territory it has to cover. Vehicular traffic in the lobby and meeting areas is heavy at times, and pedestrian areas are not well marked nor protected. I chose not to entrust my vehicle to the valets after watching another guest's car being used to bulldoze speed bumps and potholes en route to the (very conveniently located) valet lot. Standard rooms are smallish for a resort setting and furnishings (also FLW-type craftsman designs) look dated, with visible wear and neglect. Ditto the bath plumbing and appointments - the sense is high-dollar, but aging. Beds were comfortable, with proper pillows and comforters, but the luxury effect was ruined by cheap, thin sheets. In-room dining is Holiday Inn standard, not resort-style by any means, with standard plastic trays littering the corridors. Our family ordered pizzas; they were expensive, soggy and delivered in the standard cardboard box. Used service items were not removed promptly (actually, not removed at all prior to our departure)! We settled our account at checkout, then were surprised with a late charge to our credit card for mini-fridge items we did not use. It took three phone calls to reach someone in the accounts department with authority to remove the charge - and this was done grudgingly and with implied disbelief. This is a beautiful, elegant but aging resort property trading on location, its ”Wright-influenced” architecture, and a reputation for service it may have deserved at one time, but does not merit now. While the facades and public facilities may be timeless, time has passed the Biltmore by in terms of service and amenities.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful grounds, so-so room”
Reviews.Author: briebrie23
Reviews.Content: We truly enjoyed our stay at the Biltmore. The main hotel building is beautiful, and the grounds were breath-taking (literally, too, as they were scented with orange blossoms). The main pools did get very crowded during the day, but the two smaller pools weren't bad, and all were deserted by 6pm. We had a private soak in the hot tub and the giant pool entirely to ourselves at 9pm. (and it was in the 90s that week, so it can't have been the weather!) Food and drink are very pricey, but no more so than at other resorts of this caliber. The only bad thing we could say was that our room itself was dated and not up to the rest of the grounds. It was spacious and very clean--we probably wouldn't have even thought it "so-so" if the rest of the hotel weren't so magnificent!

Reviews.Title: “Really Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: chowia
Reviews.Content: The resort grounds are really beautiful, the rooms were spacious, and the weather was gorgeous during our stay, but that's about the best thing I can say about our experience at the Biltmore. For a hotel property of this caliber and at this price point, I really had much higher expectations for the service that we would receive. The hotel seemed to be extremely understaffed as we noticed the same servers working full shifts at the pool and then also at the property's restaurants and lounges at night. Service was terribly slow at all of the restaurants, we waited more than 30 minutes for our waiter to bring us our check one night. On another occassion, our server brought us our drinks and when we gave her exact change (including tip), she exclaimed "you guys are my favorite customers because now I don't have to come back and check on you." We sat outside at this lounge for 5 more hours that night and she never did come back and ask us if we wanted another drink. That experience pretty much sums up our whole stay. I have paid 1/3 the cost at other hotels and gotten far better service than I got at the Biltmore. In my opinion, this property is definitely not worth the money. I would return to this hotel only if the room rate was under $200/night.

Reviews.Title: “had a wonderful time, but you do need to be aware of a few things”
Reviews.Author: danbull
Reviews.Content: The property is beautiful, and extremely well maintained. all of the employees were very helpful. We stayed in the paradise wing. room was ok, nothing that i haven't seen before. the things to be aware of are the pricing of items such as drinks (cokes) is typical resort pricing. the main pool area fills up very quickly, making it almost impossible to find a spot to sit. so prepare to get by the pool early. other than that, it was a nice stay.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful hotel. Great value. We are excited to return!”
Reviews.Author: StephSkrzys
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Arizona Biltmore for an extended weekend and our expectations were definitely exceeded. The resort grounds were very nice. There were several different pools. One had a swim-up bar that drew a crowd. The location was perfect, with a shuttle going to the Scottsdale area that was less than one mile away. Every morning we enjoyed their gym and spa area, which provided fresh fruit and juice, which were amazing! Overall, we had a wonderful time and feel this was a bargain!

Reviews.Title: “5-star service and architecture, 3-star room”
Reviews.Author: DenverBrian
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore is stunning in its architecture and grounds and a fantastic place to plop down in Phoenix during the spring. If you're a fan of mid-century modern, you'll love exploring. Be sure to peek into the conference room spaces, some with soaring gold peaked ceilings - truly unique in design. I encountered true 5-star service from all staff during my stay, including a charming houseman who greeted me in English and then, when I asked for directions to the spa, provided me precise information - in Spanish! Because of his friendly body language and gestures, I was able to infer where to go and when I confirmed it with him ("Oh, across the pool...I see!") he smiled and said "Yes sir!" This kind of interaction is sooooo much better than the typical eyes-down, mumbling "no englais" response one might receive at other properties. As others have noted, the Biltmore is a bit pretentious when it comes to pricing. Even in the gift shop, a 12-oz. can of soda fetches $2.50 - God knows what it is from the minibar. The Biltmore's biggest opportunity for improvement is in the room itself. Once inside it's as if you're suddenly transported to a typical Marriott in a city center location. Large armoires hold a smallish 20-inch tube TV; if they'd banish the armoire and install a proper 42" flat screen, they'd gain substantial psychological space in the rooms. The rooms aren't tiny, but they're below 21st century standards for space. Bathrooms are somewhat cramped, but at least the tub/shower combo is a roomy six-plus-footer so even men can lie fully in the water if they choose. Rainshower heads help when taking a shower. Only a single sink but a wide vanity and an extra full-length shelf above help store toiletries over a multi-night stay. Closets are ample and lighted by opening the door automatically. Beds are new Serta mattresses in the same quality range as the Westin Heavenly Bed, and they include a substantial down topper (removable if too hot during the summer). However, the Biltmore ruins the effect by using cheap 60/40 blend sheets instead of the all-cotton sheets virtually every 5-star property uses these days. Furniture in the rooms is somewhat dated, with a craftsman style but worn and de-laminating tops on many surfaces. Decor is very desert-style but lacks color - too much beige/brown/terra cotta, not any bold color to break up the palette, even in the artwork or accent pillows. Despite the build date of 1929 (or perhaps BECAUSE of it), the room was quiet - and I was in the main building above the lobby. If in the main building, third floor, odd numbers will provide a reasonable view. In-room dining also falls far below a 5-star standard. No roll-in cart here - it's delivered on an uninspired tray with the single indulgence being a fresh-cut whole flower and long stem adorning the side. I ordered a pizza; it came in a delivery cardboard box. 5-star properties that get this right deliver on a silver platter with cover. For its central location and local history, the Biltmore is a hotel you should stay in at least once. You'll have to decide after that if it's worth returning.

Reviews.Title: “Great Facilities/Disorganized for the business traveler”
Reviews.Author: cv59
Reviews.Content: The outdoor facilities and grounds are great. Make sure not to book a room in the terrace wing as the rooms and pool there are upscale Motel 6. The business center is a mess organizationally: My office confirmed a Federal Express via tracking # that a Federal Express box was delivered to me at the Arizona Biltmore at 10:35 AM. At noon I was still on the phone with the "shipping office" trying to locate the box. This after 5 previous conversations with the front desk, business office, manager's office (who, interestingly advised that this could be Federal Express' fault as they sometimes mark in their truck that that they have made a delivery when in fact they have not). Finally, at 12:05 PM, the truly helpful Jennifer in the shipping office advised that the Federal Express had been located and that it in fact was delivered at 10:35 AM. Unacceptable processing for a property that touts itself as confererence center and business hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: justgardens
Reviews.Content: This review is relative to price and expectations. This hotel was probably very good at one time. However, I believe they are still living in the past. The facilities were OK but the service was certainly subpar. Most of the staff would not make eye contact or speak to you. Part of the problem was that many of them could not speak english. Some of them bordered on being rude but they may have been just shy. Everything was overpriced. You got the feeling that they thought they could charge whatever they wanted because they were "The Biltmore". They "nickeled and dimed" you on about everything. They charged an annoying $16.00 per day "resort fee". Their valet was $24.00 per day and sometimes, when you would call for your car, they would tell you that they could not get it in advance. It was first come, first served when you got there. What a joke! I have stayed at some of the finest hotels in the world and this is certainly not one of them even tho they might think so. I stayed at much better resorts for a lot less. I am sure Phoenix has much better to offer than this place. Don't be fooled by their past reputation.

Reviews.Title: “i loved it”
Reviews.Author: terri011
Reviews.Content: the resort was amazing there was enough space and there was a lot to do. I was not at all bored.

Reviews.Title: “The Negative Reviews are Correct”
Reviews.Author: Critical_But_Fair
Reviews.Content: The ONLY reason to stay at this resort is if you love Frank Lloyd-Wright-INSPIRED architecture (he was merely a consultant to the architecht-of-record). Admittedly, the main building's exterior and interior are stunning and worth seeing, even if you are not an architecture buff. It is probably one of the most beautiful hotel lobbies in the world. However, once you get past the main public areas, everything changes for the very worse. The rooms are not a good value (conference rate is $300) and, more importantly for me, the service is erratic and mostly well below average. My wife and I stayed at this resort for four nights, which gave us time to get to know a number of the staff, particularly those working in the lobby area. They are generally very good people, but I believe they (and, consequently, the guests) are victims of horrible service training. Too many times I had to call a manager over or begin to make a scene before I would receive the service you deserve at a self-proclaimed high-end hotel. For example, most nights it was nearly impossible to find a server on patio areas near the fire pits. Once, I went inside to the bar and asked a server for assistance. She told me that the patio was not her area and that she could not help me. I found the chief bartender and told him about my exchange. He apologized and took my drink order. Later, the server came outside and offered help; she then explained that she had been trained not to "take over" another server's area. I doubt very much you would ever have a Four Seasons or Ritz employee say "No" to a simple and reasonable request. Upon check-in, I was informed that I did not have a reservation for my first night, despite having the email confirmation with the correct dates with me. The front desk clerk was unimpressed when I showed him the email (he didn't even look at it). He commented that the hotel was full and that I may have to come back the next day. Only after I told him that it was his obligation to comply with my reservation did he offer me a suite at a discounted price. The suite was large, but, as another reviewer commented, it was appointed like an Embassy Suites. Also, my wife and I could hear every noise and tidbit of conversation coming from the closed off adjoining room (and they could hear us, too). Several ordinary requests from housekeeping went unfulfilled. I ordered some snacks and a small bottle of vermouth (retail price in Ohio is $6) from room service. When the employee finally arrived, the bill indicated that the vermouth was $75! I refused the bottle, but the employee explained that I would first have to talk to the manager. I refused to do so and sent the server away with the bottle. You get the drift. Beautiful hotel. Lousy service (more accurately: very poor training by Hilton, the manager). I will never recommend someone stay here, but it is worth a visit just to look around.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed review”
Reviews.Author: nwwriter
Reviews.Content: This is truly a historic hotel and a must see for anyone visiting Phoenix. However, we found the hotel to be stuffy and pretentious, and never felt truly comfortable there. The rooms are only average, and the staff were not friendly. It's also very expensive. I guess it's great that we can say we stayed there, but it's a better place to stop by and see rather than stay.

Reviews.Title: “really average hotel”
Reviews.Author: slumberdudes
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at this hotel for combination business and leisure. It was our second stay at the Biltmore and all in all it was very average and not worth the premium rates they charge. the hotel's decor is a little dated but the grounds, especially at night, are beautiful. The outside fire pits are great on cool nights. The interior of the rooms was tired. Good bed, nice flat screen tv but the chairs, desk, carpet etc are worn and need a little updating. Bathroom was small and drafty. $20 per day for internet and gym/spa was ok . Gym was adequate. Room service food was bad! Hospitality items in room were way over priced - $5 for a small bottle of water!! Biltmore Grill was good and the waitress (Rebecca) was excellent. Front desk staff was ambivalent at best. When we asked for directions within the hotel (which is sprawling) the concierge was not helpful and he acted like he was doing me a BIG favor. Front door staff seemed more interested in chatting among themselves than assisting us with luggage and directions. Executive cars were available, but $15 for a 1 mile ride to the mall was excessive. Meeting rooms were newer and good though food was less than average. You can get the best of this hotel by stopping by at sunset for a drink and a stroll on the grounds. Otherwise if you are being charged for a 5 star experience it is not worth it.

Reviews.Title: “NOT a five star hotel--no way”
Reviews.Author: girlbird
Reviews.Content: NOT a five star by any stretch of the imagination. A two or three at most. Overpriced to the nth degree. Do NOT believe good reviews about this place, really truly. I can't imagine why anybody would stay here at these prices. I am used to five star places and love that level of service. When in Phoenix, stay anywhere but here. PROS: The golf course was ok. The architecture of the main building is really interesting, especially at night. Worth a trip if your'e into that. However... The service on the links was awful. The architecture is not Frank Lloyd Wright, however. It's just inspried by him. Worse yet, everything except the lobby and the main common areas have been gutted beyond recognition, like by the worst common denominator 70s Hilton type mediocrity. The pools are nice, but badly updated. Even the rooms have tacky arts and crafts knock off fake furniture you'd see at an Embassy Suites. So if you want to stay here for the architecture, forget it. Stop by and have a drink at the bar, walk around for ten minutes, but stay somewhere else. They took the soul out of this 1929 resort. Having said that, if only the Four Seasons or somebody would restore it to look original 1929 and take over management, it could be a special place, like the many upscale mid-century places in Palm Srings. CONS: During my stay, a partial list: They mow the lawn at 7:30 am with really loud mowers. The tv stations didn't work. No internet in the room, and the business center charged $40 per hour!! EVERYTHING is overpriced as to be a joke!! The porno cost $15 per movie. Sheesh! The honor bar was higway robbery: The teeny little water bottle was $5. This is the desert for heaven's sake--no complimentary water?? The teeny little half coke bottle was $5.50. The thing of cashews, all 23 of them, cost $11. There are flourescent lights in the rooms. I love the environment and all, but flourescent lighting is the worst cheapskate thing in a nice hotel. The gifts shops had tacky tacky 1980 preppie stuff. The food was HORRIFIC. At the Grill, at the Wrights dining room--it's as if the cook saw a picture of a fancy restaurant in NYC or San Francisco, and made the food look like the picture, but the tastes are truly gruesome. Bad tomatoes, broken recipes. The shrimp was yellow, the fish and chips frozen. The staff do not respect the do not distirb signs--we're talking three or four knocks late at night kind of thing. The staff is rather ignorant--they mean well, but they don't have the hotel to back it up. This is really not a good place to spend money. The list of activities is a joke, and everything costs a fortune to do it.

Reviews.Title: “Can't wait to return.”
Reviews.Author: penguinitis
Reviews.Content: This property is superb! This was our second visit, and the reservations department had our file up and our preferences in place. I do wish that there was an additional place to eat breakfast or dinner on the grounds. The lines were longer than I expected, even with reservations.

Reviews.Title: “Bilkmore”
Reviews.Author: iwanttowin
Reviews.Content: The property itself is beautiful and well maintained. The service is another thing altogether. The fridges are well stocked, but don't dare move anything out of the fridge, even if you have no intention on consuming it. You'll be charged an arm and a leg. Mysterious extra charges have appeared on credit cards from numerous people in my group of several hundred that stayed there for a convention this past summer. The hotel was most unhelpful to rectify the situation. Months later, more charges mysteriously appear without explanation. Don't waste your time and money at this place. It's the BilKmore!

Reviews.Title: “Horrific, overrated hotel!”
Reviews.Author: santoki
Reviews.Content: I was disappointed with this hotel from the second I walked onto the property, then things progressed from bad to horrible. First, check-in was excruciatingly slow and though the reception employee was pleasant, she didn't seem to know what she was doing. I'd say we waited a full 10 minutes before she found us a room. When she showed us where the room was on a map, it looked really far away. When I asked for one closer, she said none was available, but she said that to compensate for the distance, she had given up one of the special, luxury rooms. She whispered that this room goes for $1,000.00 a night - HA! - what a joke that turned out to be. We had to walk outside to get to the room - as it did not connect with the main building. It was over 100 degrees outside and no bell hops were available to help us with our numerous suitcases. We were both sweating by the time - 15-20 minutes later - we got to the room. And the room was a joke - tiny, with poor decor. There was no way it was worth 1K per night let only $100. So, we trudged back to the reception desk, and I explained our dissatisfaction, esp. with the distance - and lo and behold - a room was suddenly available. It was still a bit of a walk, but manageable. The nightmare started on the second day when we discovered - very late at night - that our closet was flooded. All our clothes - those on the shelves and on the hangers were soaked. This was at midnight. The manager said he'd send someone to pick up our clothes and get them dried. I explained that my husband didn't have any clothes left at all since all of his had been in the closet. When we got our laundry back, several items were missing. I advised the front desk, and then a manager, who said he'd follow up and get back to me within 30 minutes. An hour later, I went to the front desk to see him, and he was chatting and joking with an employee. He hadn't even begun to do anything. I checked back another hour later, and he said he didn't know what had happened, but that he'd have the laundry manager call us in the morning. He explained that the manager got in at 6a.m. I advised him to NOT call our room before 9am. I even wrote a note to this effect to leave with the laundry manager. Well, guess what, we were awakened at 6:00 am. I was so furious. He had not found our clothes - he called just to tell me that they were still missing. In the end, our clothes were not recovered, and with no explanation as to why. On top of all this, everything was ridiculously overpriced. A can (not even a bottle) of Coke was $3.50., a stick of deodorant was $8.00. Room service was extortionate and the food at the deli and restaurant (another restaurant was closed for the duration of our stay) was mediocre at best. The service at the bar was very slow. The staff generally seemed inexperienced. The worst was the billing. Our bill at check-out was twice what it should have been. We had to delay our departure getting that settled. Much worse than that, many others in our group found excess, unexplained charges on their credit card bill - a dozen reported they were billed for additional amounts as recenlty as last week - almost 5 months after our stay! So, overall - one of the worst hotel stays I've ever had. I would not go there again if it were free!

Reviews.Title: “Frank Lloyd Wright Heaven”
Reviews.Author: Spy-Guy-Dad
Reviews.Content: Our second trip to the Arizona Biltmore was even better than the first. We went in 2005 for two nights after traveling throughout the southwest. This year (2006) was for seven nights. Although not designed by Wright (as some think), his influence as consultant pervades the entire complex. Numerous pools, a variety of lodging options, and fabulous restaurant (Wright's) makes for a great stay.

Reviews.Title: “Historic Resort”
Reviews.Author: regosnell
Reviews.Content: This is a very classic and historic hotel, one of a kind. The grounds are beautiful, every president since Herbert Hoover has stayed here as well as many of the celeb's from the 40's, 50's and 60's. It is worth staying here just to be a part of that history. However, simple things like not having a coffee maker in your room can be annoying, especially for the price you are paying.

Reviews.Title: “4 Star Grounds, 1-3 Star Service”
Reviews.Author: applegator
Reviews.Content: Arriving at the Arizona Biltmore gives you a sense of what a "5-star" resort must have been like for movie stars and millionaires during the early part of the last century. You can tell that the place definitely had its moments of elite history, and while it may have truly been one of the most glamourous hotels back then, it shows its age in both good and bad ways. It's as if, as another reviewer noted, that management can't decide if it wants to embrace its past or evolve into some vision of a Las Vegas resort future. The lobby area is truly lovely, cozy and inviting, if a little schizo. There's clearly Asian influences, southwestern influences and, oddly enough, a sense of pacific northwest lodges here. That's the interior... the outside is a different story. The "iconic element" of this resort are the building tiles that cover everything (and I mean everything) all rendered in glorious greenish concrete. The property loves to drop Frank Lloyd Wright's name, and I can see the influence. That is, if FLW designed a hospital. It's very institutional and the buildings just look a bit like a very well maintained "sanitarium" from the 1920's. Luckily, the interior of my room was a different story. Very, very spacious and well-appointed. A few small gripes: - The desk chairs are not well padded.
